message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest infective endocarditis, and the most common organism causing it in patients with a previous valve replacement is Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus spp. The other options are less commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s past medical history of mitral valve replacement indicates that the most likely cause of his symptoms is a prosthetic valve endocarditis. Among the options, coagulase-negative Staphylococcus spp. is commonly associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis. Candida albicans can also cause endocarditis, but it is less likely in this case. Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Escherichia coli are not commonly associated with endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and past medical history suggest infective endocarditis following valve replacement. Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus spp. is the most common organism responsible for early-onset prosthetic valve endocarditis. The other options are not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

None of the other options are typically associated with infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low-grade fever, malaise, weight loss, and new onset heart murmur suggest infective endocarditis. Among the options, Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus spp. is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in patients with prosthetic valves. Candida albicans can also cause infective endocarditis but is less common. Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Escherichia coli are not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.
